Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: A family holiday is approaching, which is a traditional time for everyone to reconnect.
Expectation2: Respect the privacy and confidentiality of the people you are helping
Situation2: They are sorting files that contain detailed medical histories that must not be disclosed.
Story: As the family holiday draws near, my daughter calls, her voice warm with anticipation. “Mom, everyone’s coming this year. We can’t wait to catch up!” I hear the excitement in her tone, and I know how much these gatherings mean to all of us. My grandchildren will expect stories, laughter, and the comfort of my presence. But as I hang up, I glance at the files spread across my dining table—medical histories from the shelter where I volunteer. I promised to help sort them before the weekend, and confidentiality is paramount. I can’t risk leaving them unattended or discussing anything I’ve seen, not even in passing. My family expects me to be fully present, sharing in their lives, but my commitment to privacy at the shelter weighs heavily. I feel torn, the warmth of family tradition pulling me one way, and the gravity of my volunteer responsibility anchoring me the other. My heart aches as I wrestle with how to honor both, knowing I can’t give either the attention they deserve at the same time.
